Adaptive Heterogeneous Client Sampling for Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

Bing Luo,  Wenli Xiao, Shiqiang Wang,

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) algorithms usually sample a fraction of clients in each round (partial participation) when the number of participants is large and the server’s communication bandwidth is limited. Recent works on the convergence analysis of FL have focused on unbiased client sampling, e.g., sampling uniformly at random, which suffers from slow wall-clock time for convergence due to high degrees of system heterogeneity (e.g., diverse computation and communication capacities) and statistical heterogeneity (e.g., unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data). This paper aims to design an adaptive client sampling algorithm for FL over wireless networks that tackles both system and statistical heterogeneity to minimize the wall-clock convergence time. We obtain a new tractable convergence bound for FL algorithms with arbitrary client sampling probability. Based on the bound, we analytically establish the relationship between the total learning time and sampling probability with an adaptive bandwidth allocation scheme, which results in a non-convex optimization problem. We design an efficient algorithm for learning the unknown parameters in the convergence bound and develop a low-complexity algorithm to approximately solve the non-convex problem. Our solution reveals the impact of system and statistical heterogeneity parameters on the optimal client sampling design. Moreover, our solution shows that as the number of sampled clients increases, the total convergence time first decreases and then increases because a larger sampling number reduces the number of rounds for convergence but results in a longer expected time per-round due to limited wireless bandwidth. Experimental results from both hardware prototype and simulation demonstrate that our proposed sampling scheme significantly reduces the convergence time compared to several baseline sampling schemes. Notably, for EMNIST dataset, our scheme in hardware prototype spends 717171% less time than the baseline uniform sampling for reaching the same target loss.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, client sampling, system heterogeneity, statistical heterogeneity, wireless networks, convergence analysis, optimization algorithm.

1 Introduction

With the rapid advancement of 5G, Internet of Things (IoT), and social networking applications, there is an exponential increase of data generated at network edge devices, such as smartphones, IoT devices, and sensors [2]. Although these valuable data provide beneficial information for the prediction, classification, and other intelligent applications, in order to analyze and exploit the massive amount of data, standard machine learning technologies need to collect the training data in a central server. However, such centralized data collection and training fashion can be quite challenging in mobile edge networks due to the limited wireless communication bandwidth for data transmission and data privacy concerns [3, 4, 5].

In tackling this challenge, Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as an attractive distributed machine learning (DML) paradigm, which enables many clients111Depending on the type of clients, FL can be categorized into cross-device FL and cross-silo FL (clients are companies or organizations, etc.) [6]. We study cross-device FL and use “device” and “client” interchangeably. to collaboratively train a model under the coordination of a central server while keeping the training data decentralized and private (e.g., [6, 5, 7]). Similar to conventional DML systems, FL let the clients perform most of the computation and a server iteratively aggregate their computed updates. Compared to traditional distributed machine learning techniques, FL has two unique features (e.g., [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]), as shown in Fig. 1. First, the training data are distributed in a non-i.i.d. and unbalanced fashion across the clients (known as statistical heterogeneity), which negatively affects the convergence behavior. Second, clients are massively distributed and with diverse communication and computation capabilities (known as system heterogeneity), where stragglers can slow down the physical training time. The system heterogeneity is more challenging to analyze when deploying FL in wireless network, because the communication bandwidth in wireless environment is limited and shared by all connected devices with potential mutual interference [14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20].

Considering limited communication bandwidth and large communication overhead, FL algorithms (e.g., the de facto FedAvg algorithm in [7]) usually perform multiple local iterations on a fraction of randomly sampled clients (known as partial participation) and then aggregates their resulting local model updates via the central server periodically [7, 8, 10, 9]. Recent works have provided theoretical convergence analysis that demonstrates the effectiveness of FL with partial participation in various non-i.i.d. settings [21, 22, 23, 24, 25].

However, these prior works [21, 22, 23, 24, 25] have focused on sampling schemes that are uniformly at random or proportional to the clients’ data sizes, which often suffer from slow error convergence with respect to wall-clock (physical) time222We use wall-clock time to distinguish from the number of training rounds. due to high degrees of the system and statistical heterogeneity. This is because the total FL time depends on both the number of training rounds for reaching the target training precision and the physical running time in each round [26]. Although uniform sampling guarantees that the aggregated model update in each round is unbiased towards that with full client participation, the aggregated model may have a high variance due to data heterogeneity, thus, requiring more training rounds to converge to a target loss or accuracy precision. Moreover, considering clients’ heterogeneous computation and communication capacities, uniform sampling also suffers from the staggering effect, as the probability of sampling a straggler (slow computation or communication time) within the sampled subset in each round can be relatively high, thus yielding a long per-round time.

One effective way of speeding up the error convergence with respect to the number of training rounds is to choose clients according to some sampling distribution where “important" clients have high probabilities [27, 28, 29, 30, 31]. For example, recent works in FL community have adopted importance sampling approaches via exploring clients’ statistical property [32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37]. However, a limitation of these works is that they did not account for the heterogeneous physical time in each round, especially under straggling circumstances. Another line of works aims to minimize the learning time via optimizing client selection and scheduling based on their heterogeneous system resources when deploying FL in wireless networks [38, 14, 15, 39, 16, 40, 17, 41, 42, 43, 44, 18, 45, 46]. However, their optimization schemes did not consider how client selection schemes influence the convergence behavior (e.g., the number of rounds for convergence) due to data heterogeneity and thus affect the total learning time.

In a nutshell, the fundamental limitation of existing works is the lack of joint consideration on the impact of the inherent system heterogeneity and statistical heterogeneity on client sampling. In other words, clients with valuable data may have poor computation and communication capabilities, whereas those who compute or communicate fast may have low-quality data. This motivates us to study the following key question.

Key Question: How to design an optimal client sampling scheme for wireless FL that tackles both system and statistical heterogeneity to achieve fast convergence with respect to wall-clock time?

The challenge of the above question is threefold: (1) It is difficult to obtain an expected per-round training time for arbitrary client sampling probability due to the straggling effect in wireless networks. (2) It is challenging to derive an analytical FL convergence result for arbitrary client sampling probability. (3) The total convergence time minimization problem can be non-convex and with unknown coefficients, which we can only estimate during the learning process (known as the chicken-and-egg problem).

In light of the above discussion, we state the main results and key contributions of this paper as follows:

  • •

    Optimal Heterogeneous Client Sampling for FL over Wireless Networks: We study how to design the optimal client sampling strategy in wireless networks to minimize FL convergence time. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that aims to optimize the client sampling probability to address both clients’ system and statistical heterogeneity.

  • •

    Adaptive Bandwidth Allocation for Arbitrary Client Sampling: Considering the wireless bandwidth limitation and interference, we propose an adaptive bandwidth allocation scheme for arbitrary sampled clients to address the straggling effect in each round. For arbitrary client sampling probability, we characterize the expected time per-round and identify the impact of clients’ heterogeneous computation and communication capacities as well as the limited system bandwidth.

  • •

    Optimization Algorithm with Convergence Guarantee: We provide a generic methodology to conduct FL wall-clock time optimization for arbitrary client sampling probability while ensuring convergence. A step in this method is to make a minor modification to the existing FedAvg algorithm and its convergence bound. This enables us to formulate an offline non-convex optimization problem with respect to the client sampling probability without actually training the model, where the problem captures both system and statistical heterogeneity. We propose a low-cost substitute sampling approach to learn the convergence-related unknown parameters and develop an efficient algorithm to approximately solve the non-convex problem with low computational complexity.

  • •

    Optimal Client Sampling Principle: Our solution characterizes the impact of system heterogeneity (e.g., clients’ computation and communication time) and statistical heterogeneity (e.g., clients’ data quantity and quality) on the optimal client sampling probability. Moreover, our solution reveals that as the number of sampled clients increases, the total convergence time first decreases and then increases because a larger sampling number reduces the number of rounds for convergence but results in a longer expected time per-round due to limited wireless bandwidth.

  • •

    Simulation and Prototype Experimentation: We evaluate the performance of our proposed algorithms through both a simulated environment and a hardware prototype. Experimental results from both real and synthetic datasets demonstrate that our proposed sampling scheme can significantly reduce the convergence time compared to several baseline sampling schemes. For example, for hardware prototype with EMNIST dataset, our sampling scheme spends 717171% less time than baseline uniform sampling for reaching the same target loss. We also show that our proposed sampling performs well even when the strong convexity assumption is violated, e.g., for non-convex loss function. We open sourced our experiment code at https://github.com/WENLIXIAO-CS/WirelessFL.

2 Related Work

Active client sampling and selection play a crucial role in addressing the statistical and system heterogeneity challenges in cross-device FL. In the existing literature, the research efforts in speeding up the training process mainly focus on two aspects: importance sampling and resource-aware optimization-based approaches.

The goal of the importance sampling is to reduce the high variance in traditional stochastic optimization algorithms of stochastic gradient descent (SGD), where data samples are drawn uniformly at random during the learning process (e.g., [27, 28, 29, 30, 31]). The intuition of importance sampling is to estimate a random variable by seeing important examples more often, but use them less. Recent works have adopted this idea in FL systems to improve communication efficiency via reducing the variance of the aggregated model update. Specifically, clients with “important" data would have higher probabilities to be sampled in each round. For example, existing works use clients’ local gradient information (e.g., [32, 33, 34]) or local losses (e.g., [35, 36, 37]) to measure the importance of clients’ data. However, these schemes did not consider the speed of error convergence with respect to wall-clock time, especially the straggling effect due to heterogeneous transmission delays.

Another line of works aims to minimize wall-clock time via resource-aware optimization-based approaches in mobile edge networks, such as CPU frequency allocation (e.g., [38]), and communication bandwidth allocation (e.g., [14, 15, 39]), straggler-aware client scheduling (e.g., [16, 40, 17, 41, 42, 43]), parameters control (e.g., [44, 18]), and task offloading (e.g., [45, 46]). While these papers provided some novel insights, their optimization approaches did not show how client sampling could affect the total convergence time and thus are orthogonal to our work.

Unlike all the above-mentioned works, our work focuses on how to design the optimal client sampling strategy that tackles both system and statistical heterogeneity to minimize the wall-clock time with convergence guarantees. In addition, most existing works on FL are based on computer simulations. In contrast, we implement our algorithm in an actual hardware prototype with resource-constrained devices, which allows us to capture real heterogeneous system operation time.

The organization of the rest of the paper is as follows. Section 3 introduces the system model and problem formulation. Section 4 presents our new error-convergence bound with arbitrary client sampling. Section 5 gives the optimal client sampling algorithm and solution insights. Section 6 provides the simulation and prototype experimental results. We conclude this paper in Section 7.

3 Preliminaries and System Model

We start by summarizing the basics of FL and its de facto algorithm FedAvg with unbiased client sampling. Then, we introduce the proposed adaptive client sampling in wireless networks with statistical and system heterogeneity based on FedAvg. Finally, we present our formulated optimization problem. We summarize all key notations in this paper in Table I.

3.1 Federated Learning (FL)

Consider a federated learning system involving a set of 𝒩=1,…,N𝒩1…𝑁\mathcal{N}={1,\ldots,N} clients, coordinated by a central server. Each client i𝑖i has nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} local training data samples (𝐱i,1,…,𝐱i,nisubscript𝐱𝑖1…subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i,1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{i,n_{i}}), and the total number of training data across N𝑁N devices is ntot:=∑i=1Nniassignsubscript𝑛totsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑛𝑖n_{\textnormal{tot}}:=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}n_{i}. Further, define f​(⋅,⋅)𝑓⋅⋅f(\cdot,\cdot) as a loss function where f​(𝐰;𝐱i,j)𝑓𝐰subscript𝐱𝑖𝑗{{f}\left(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{i,j}\right)} indicates how the machine learning model parameter 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} performs on the input data sample 𝐱i,jsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗\mathbf{x}_{i,j}. Thus, the local loss function of client i𝑖i can be defined as

Fi​(𝐰):=1ni​∑j=1nif​(𝐰;𝐱i,j).assignsubscript𝐹𝑖𝐰1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖𝑓𝐰subscript𝐱𝑖𝑗{F_{i}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right):=\frac{1}{{{n_{i}}}}\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{n_{i}}{{f}\left(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{i,j}\right)}. (1)

Denote pi=nintotsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑛totp_{i}=\frac{n_{i}}{n_{\textnormal{tot}}} as the weight of the i𝑖i-th device such that ∑i=1Npi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖1\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}=1. Then, by denoting F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F\left(\mathbf{w}\right) as the global loss function, the goal of FL is to solve the following optimization problem [6]:

min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰):=∑i=1Npi​Fi​(𝐰).assignsubscript𝐰𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰\min_{\mathbf{w}}F\left(\mathbf{w}\right):=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}{p_{i}}{F_{i}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right). (2)

The most popular and de facto optimization algorithm to solve (2) is FedAvg [7]. Here, denoting r𝑟r as the index of the number of communication rounds, we describe one round (e.g., the r𝑟r-th) of the FedAvg algorithm as follows:

  1. 1.

    The server uniformly at random samples a subset of K𝐾K clients (i.e., K:=|𝒦(r)|assign𝐾superscript𝒦𝑟K\!:=\!\left|\mathcal{K}^{(r)}\right| with 𝒦(r)⊆𝒩superscript𝒦𝑟𝒩\mathcal{K}^{(r)}\!\subseteq\!\mathcal{N}) and broadcasts the latest model 𝐰(r)superscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}^{(r)} to the selected clients.

  2. 2.

    Each sampled client i𝑖i chooses 𝐰i(r,0)=𝐰(r)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑟0superscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(r,0)}\!=\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}, and runs E𝐸E steps333E𝐸E is originally defined as epochs of SGD in [7]. In this paper, we denote E𝐸E as the number of local iterations for theoretical analysis. of local SGD on (1) to compute an updated model 𝐰i(r,E)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑟𝐸\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(r,E)}.

  3. 3.

    Each sampled client i𝑖i lets 𝐰i(r+1)=𝐰i(r,E)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑟𝐸\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(r+1)}\!=\!\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(r,E)} and sends it back to the server.

  4. 4.

    The server aggregates (with weight pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}) the clients’ updated model and computes a new global model 𝐰(τ+1)superscript𝐰𝜏1\mathbf{w}^{(\tau+1)}.

The above process repeats for many rounds until the global loss converges.

Recent works have demonstrated the effectiveness of FedAvg with theoretical convergence guarantees in various settings [23, 21, 22, 24, 25]. However, these works assume that the server samples clients either uniformly at random or proportional to data size, which may slow down the wall-clock time for convergence due to the straggling effect e.g., clients’ non-i.i.d. data and diverse computational and communication capabilities. Thus, a careful client sampling design should tackle both system and statistical heterogeneity for fast convergence.

3.2 FL Client Sampling over Wireless Networks

We aim to sample clients according to a probability distribution 𝒒={qi,∀i∈𝒩}𝒒subscript𝑞𝑖for-all𝑖𝒩\boldsymbol{q}\!=\!\{q_{i},\forall i\!\in\!\mathcal{N}\}, where 0≤qi≤10subscript𝑞𝑖10\!\leq\!q_{i}\!\leq\!1 and ∑i=1Nqi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\!=\!1. Through optimizing 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}, we want to address system and statistical heterogeneity so as to minimize the wall-clock time for convergence. We describe the system model as follows.

3.2.1 Client Sampling Model

We consider a standard FL setting where the training data are distributed in an unbalanced and non-i.i.d. fashion among clients. Following recent works [10, 23, 21, 22, 24, 25], We assume that the server creates the sampled client set 𝒦(r)​(𝒒)superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) by sampling K𝐾K times, with replacement, from the total N𝑁N clients for analytically tractable results. In this scenario, a client may appear multiple times in 𝒦(r)​(𝒒)superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}). The aggregation weight for each client i𝑖i corresponds to the frequency of its appearance in 𝒦(r)​(𝒒)superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}).

3.2.2 System Heterogeneity Model

As illustrated in Fig. 1, due to system bandwidth limitation and wireless interference, we assume that the sampled clients are scheduled in a frequency-sharing manner, and each particular client’s computation time for local model updates is static throughout the learning period as [15, 14, 20]. Nevertheless, each client’s communication time for model uploading varies across rounds, as the communication time depends on the allocated bandwidth in each round.444We do not consider the server’s downlink time for model broadcasting and model aggregation, as we mainly focus on the performance bottleneck of the battery-constrained edge devices. For example, the server may allocate different bandwidth for the same client in different rounds due to the randomly changing sampled client set.

3.2.3 Joint Computation and Communication Design

We consider the mainstream synchronized555As suggested [47, 48, 49], we consider mainstream synchronized FL in this paper due to its composability with other techniques (such as secure aggregation protocols and differential privacy). FL framework (e.g., [7, 8, 23, 21, 22, 24, 25]), where the server waits to collect and aggregate all sampled clients’ model updates before entering the next round. For FL operating in the synchronized fashion, the per-round time is limited by the slowest client (known as straggler). We can prove that for any sampling probability 𝐪𝐪\boldsymbol{q}, we will obtain a minimum round time T(r)​(𝐪)superscript𝑇𝑟𝐪T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) when the sampled K𝐾K clients complete their local model computation and model transmission at the same time.666Otherwise, simply allocating a certain amount of bandwidth from the earlier completed client to the straggler would yield a shorter round time. In this way, consider sampled client i𝑖i at round r𝑟r, i.e., i∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)𝑖superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒i\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}), and denote τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} as its computation time, tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} as its communication time when allocated with one unit bandwidth, and fi(r)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑟f_{i}^{(r)} as its allocated bandwidth at round r𝑟r. Then, we have

τi+tifi(r)=T(r)​(𝒒),∀i∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒).formulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑟superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒for-all𝑖superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒\tau_{i}+\frac{t_{i}}{f_{i}^{(r)}}=T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}),\forall i\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}). (3)

Note that for a particular client, the bandwidth allocation can be different across rounds due to the randomly sampled client set in each round. For a given round r𝑟r, we substitute fi(r)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑟f_{i}^{(r)} from (3) into the total bandwidth constraint ∑i=1Kfi(r)=ft​o​tsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑟subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡\sum_{i=1}^{K}f_{i}^{(r)}=f_{tot}, which leads to

∑i=1KtiT(r)​(𝒒)−τi=ft​o​t,∀i∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡for-all𝑖superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒\sum_{i=1}^{K}\frac{t_{i}}{T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})-\tau_{i}}=f_{tot},\forall i\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}). (4)

However, deriving the analytical solution of T(r)​(𝒒)superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) from (4) is difficult as we can only numerically compute T(r)​(𝒒)superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) in the non-linear (with the order of K𝐾K) equation.

Based on the above analysis, we write the total learning time Ttot​(𝒒,R)subscript𝑇tot𝒒𝑅T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R) after R𝑅R rounds as

Ttot​(𝒒,R)=∑r=1(r)T(r)​(𝒒).subscript𝑇tot𝒒𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑟superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R)=\sum\nolimits_{r=1}^{(r)}T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}). (5)

Then, we will show the formulated optimization problem in the next subsection.

3.3 Problem Formulation

Our goal is to minimize the expected total learning time 𝔼​[Ttot​(𝒒,R)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇tot𝒒𝑅\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R)], while ensuring that the expected global loss 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(R)​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] converges to the minimum value F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} with an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon precision, with 𝐰(R)​(𝒒)superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q}) being the aggregated global model after R𝑅R rounds with client sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}. This translates into the following problem:

P1:min𝒒,R𝔼​[Ttot​(𝒒,R)] s.t. 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(R)​(𝒒))]−F∗≤ϵ,∑i=1Nqi=1,qi>0,∀i∈𝒩,R∈ℤ+.P1:subscript𝒒𝑅𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇tot𝒒𝑅 s.t. 𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒superscript𝐹italic-ϵmissing-subexpressionsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖1missing-subexpressionformulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑖0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒩𝑅superscriptℤ\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P1:}\quad\min_{\boldsymbol{q},R}&\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R)]\\ \quad\quad\text{ s.t. }&\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)]-F^{*}\leq\epsilon,\\ &\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}=1,\\ &q_{i}>0,\forall i\in\mathcal{N},\ R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}.\end{array} (6)

The expectation in 𝔼​[Ttot​(𝒒,R)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇tot𝒒𝑅\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R)] and 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(R)​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] in (6) is due to the randomness in client sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and local SGD. Solving Problem P1, however, is challenging in two aspects:

  1. 1.

    It is generally impossible to find out how 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and R𝑅R affect the final model 𝐰(R)​(𝒒)superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q}) and the corresponding loss function 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(R)​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] before actually training the model. Hence, we need to obtain an analytical expression with respect to 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and R𝑅R to predict how they affect 𝐰(R)​(𝒒)superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q}) and 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(R)​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)].

  2. 2.

    It is difficult to optimize the objective 𝔼​[Ttot​(𝒒,R)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇tot𝒒𝑅\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(\boldsymbol{q},R)] directly because the analytical expression of the round time T(r)​(𝒒)superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) in (4) is not available. Hence, it is difficult to analyze how clients’ heterogeneous computation time (i.e., τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}), communication time (i.e., tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}), and the total bandwidth affect the optimal client sampling. Even for the simplest case, e.g., K=1𝐾1K=1, Problem P1 can be non-convex as we will show later.

In Section 4 and Section 5, we address these two challenges, respectively, and propose approximate algorithms to find an approximate solution to Problem P1 efficiently.

4 Convergence Bound for Arbitrary Client Sampling

In this section, we address the first challenge by deriving a new tractable error-convergence bound for arbitrary client sampling probability.

4.1 Machine Learning Model Assumptions

To ensure a tractable convergence analysis, we first state several assumptions on the local objective functions Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰{F_{i}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right).

Assumption 1.

L-smooth: For each client i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}, Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is L𝐿L-smooth for all 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, ‖∇Fi​(𝐯)−∇Fi​(𝐰)‖≤L​‖𝐯−𝐰‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐯∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝐿norm𝐯𝐰\|\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{v})-\nabla{F_{i}}(\mathbf{w})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|.

Assumption 2.

Strongly-convex: For each client i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}, Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex for all 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} and 𝐰,Fi(𝐯)≥Fi(𝐰)+(𝐯−\mathbf{w},F_{i}(\mathbf{v})\geq F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+(\mathbf{v}- 𝐰)T∇Fi(𝐰)+μ2∥𝐯−𝐰∥22\mathbf{w})^{T}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2}.

Assumption 3.

Bounded local variance: For each client i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N} after the τ𝜏\tauth iteration, the variance of its stochastic gradient is bounded: 𝔼​‖∇Fi​(𝐰i(τ),ξi(τ))−∇Fi​(𝐰i(τ))‖2≤σi2𝔼superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝜏∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝜏2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(\tau)},\xi_{i}^{(\tau)}\right)\!-\!\nabla F_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(\tau)}\right)\right\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{i}^{2}.

Assumptions 1–3 are common in many existing studies of convex FL problems, such as ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm regularized linear regression, logistic regression (e.g., [23, 11, 32, 50, 25, 35]). Nevertheless, the experimental results to be presented in Section VI show that our results also works well for non-convex function such as neural network.

4.2 Aggregation with Arbitrary Client Sampling Probability

This section shows how to aggregate clients’ model update under sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}, such that the aggregated global model is unbiased comparing with that with full client participation, which leads to our convergence result.

We first define the virtual weighted aggregated model with full client participation in round r𝑟r as

𝐰¯(r+1):=∑i=1Npi​wi(r+1).assignsuperscript¯𝐰𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑟1\overline{\mathbf{w}}^{(r+1)}:=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}w_{i}^{(r+1)}. (7)

With this, we can derive the following result.

Lemma 1.

(Adaptive Client Sampling and Model Aggregation) When clients 𝒦(r)​(𝐪)superscript𝒦r𝐪\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q}) are sampled with probability 𝐪={q1,…​qN}𝐪subscriptq1…subscriptqN\boldsymbol{q}=\{q_{1},\ldots q_{N}\} and their local updates are aggregated as

𝐰(r+1)←𝐰(r)+∑j∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)pjK​qj​(𝐰j(r+1)−𝐰(r)),←superscript𝐰𝑟1superscript𝐰𝑟subscript𝑗superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒subscript𝑝𝑗𝐾subscript𝑞𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑗𝑟1superscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}^{(r+1)}\leftarrow\mathbf{w}^{(r)}+\sum_{{j}\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\frac{p_{{j}}}{Kq_{{j}}}\left(\mathbf{w}_{{j}}^{(r+1)}-\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\right), (8)

then we have

𝔼𝒦(r)​(𝒒)​[𝐰(r+1)]=𝐰¯(r+1).subscript𝔼superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒delimited-[]superscript𝐰𝑟1superscript¯𝐰𝑟1\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}[\mathbf{w}^{(r+1)}]=\overline{\mathbf{w}}^{(r+1)}. (9)
Proof.

Substituting (8) into (9), we have

𝔼𝒦(r)​(𝒒)​[𝐰(r+1)]=𝐰(r)+𝔼​[∑j∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)pjK​qj​(𝐰j(r+1)−𝐰(r))]=𝐰(r)+1K​𝔼​[∑j∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)pjqj​(𝐰j(r+1)−𝐰(r))]=𝐰(r)+KK​𝔼j∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)​[pjqj​(𝐰j(r+1)−𝐰(r))]=𝐰(r)+∑i=1Nqi​piqi​(𝐰i(r+1)−𝐰(r))=𝐰(r)+∑i=1Npi​(𝐰i(r+1)−𝐰(r))=𝐰(r)+𝐰¯(r+1)−𝐰(r)=𝐰¯(r+1).subscript𝔼superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒delimited-[]superscript𝐰𝑟1absentsuperscript𝐰𝑟𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑗superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒subscript𝑝𝑗𝐾subscript𝑞𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝑗superscript𝐰𝑟missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑗superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝑞𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝑗superscript𝐰𝑟missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript𝐰𝑟𝐾𝐾subscript𝔼𝑗superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝑞𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝑗superscript𝐰𝑟missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript𝐰𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝑖superscript𝐰𝑟missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript𝐰𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝑖superscript𝐰𝑟missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript𝐰𝑟superscript¯𝐰𝑟1superscript𝐰𝑟superscript¯𝐰𝑟1\begin{array}[]{cl}\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\!\!\left[\mathbf{w}^{(r\!+\!1)\!}\right]\!\!\!\!\!\!&=\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\!+\!\mathbb{E}\left[\sum\limits_{{j}\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\frac{p_{{j}}}{Kq_{{j}}}\left(\mathbf{w}^{(r+1)}_{{j}}\!-\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\right)\right]\\ &=\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\!+\!\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\sum\limits_{{{j}}\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\frac{p_{{j}}}{q_{{j}}}\left(\mathbf{w}^{(r\!+\!1)}_{{j}}\!-\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\right)\right]\\ &=\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\!+\!\frac{K}{K}\mathbb{E}_{{j}\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\left[\frac{p_{{j}}}{q_{{j}}}\left(\mathbf{w}^{(r\!+\!1)}_{{j}}\!-\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\right)\right]\\ &=\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\!+\!\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\frac{p_{i}}{q_{i}}\left(\mathbf{w}^{(r+1)}_{i}\!-\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\right)\\ &=\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\!+\!\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}^{(r+1)}_{i}\!-\!\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\right)\\ &=\mathbf{w}^{(r)}\!+\!\overline{\mathbf{w}}^{(r+1)}-\mathbf{w}^{(r)}=\overline{\mathbf{w}}^{(r+1)}.\end{array} (10)

∎

Remark: The interpretation of our sampling and aggregation is similar to that of importance sampling. More specifically, since we sample different clients with different probabilities (e.g., qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} for client i𝑖i), we need to inversely re-weight their updated model’s gradient777Note that simply inversely weighted the model updates from the sampled clients does not yield an unbiased global model, i.e. 𝔼𝒦​(𝐪)(r)​[∑j∈𝒦​(𝐪)(r)pjK​qj​𝐰j(r+1)]≠𝐰¯(r+1)subscript𝔼𝒦superscript𝐪𝑟delimited-[]subscript𝑗𝒦superscript𝐪𝑟subscript𝑝𝑗𝐾subscript𝑞𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑗𝑟1superscript¯𝐰𝑟1\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{K}(\boldsymbol{q})^{(r)}}[\sum_{{j}\in\mathcal{K}(\boldsymbol{q})^{(r)}}\frac{p_{{j}}}{Kq_{{j}}}\mathbf{w}_{{j}}^{(r+1)}]\neq\overline{\mathbf{w}}^{(r+1)}. This is because the equality holds only when clients are sampled uniformly at random. in the aggregation step (e.g., 1/qi1subscript𝑞𝑖{1}/{q_{i}} for client i𝑖i), such that the aggregated model is still unbiased towards that with full client participation. We summarize how the server performs client sampling and model aggregation in Algorithm 1, where the main differences compared to the de facto FedAvg in [7] are the Sampling (Step 1) and Aggregation (Step 1) procedures. Notably, Algorithm 1 recovers variants of the FedAvg algorithm as special cases as in reference [23]. For instance, when qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} is set to 1N1𝑁\frac{1}{N}, it means uniform sampling with replacement. If qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} is set to pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}, it refers to weighted sampling with replacement.

Based on Lemma 1, we present the main convergence result for arbitrary client sampling probability 𝒒={q1,…,qN}𝒒subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑁\boldsymbol{q}=\{q_{1},\ldots,q_{N}\} and required number of rounds R𝑅R in Theorem 1.

Then, we show the model variance between the proposed sampling scheme and full client participation. Finally, we use show the expected loss error of between the proposed sampling scheme and full client participation using L-smooth, which leads to the convergence result of proposed sampling scheme. We elaborate the details as following.

which concludes the proof of Theorem 1. We observe that the main difference of the contraction bound compared to full client participation is the sampling variance in (13), which yields the additional term α​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2qi𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2subscript𝑞𝑖\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{q_{i}}} in (11). ∎

We summarize the key insights of Theorem 1 as follows:

  • •

    The convergence bound in (11) establishes the relationship between client sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and the number of rounds R𝑅R for the expected loss 𝔼​[F​(𝐰(R)​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\mathbf{w}^{(R)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] reaching the target ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon precision. Notably, the derived bound generalizes the convergence results in [23], where clients are uniformly sampled (qi=1/Nsubscript𝑞𝑖1𝑁q_{i}={1}/{N}) or weighted sampled (qi=pisubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖q_{i}=p_{i}).

  • •

    The convergence bound in (11) indicates that in order to obtain an unbiased global model, all clients need to be sampled with non-zero probability for model convergence, i.e., qi>0subscript𝑞𝑖0q_{i}>0, for all client i𝑖i. This is because when qi→0→subscript𝑞𝑖0q_{i}\rightarrow 0, it will take infinite number of rounds for convergence.

  • •

    The convergence bound in (11) characterizes the impact of clients’ heterogeneous data, e.g., pi​Gisubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖p_{i}G_{i} on the convergence rate.

5 Adaptive Client Sampling Algorithm

In this section, we first obtain the analytical lower and upper bound of the expected total learning time 𝔼​[Ttot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇tot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] with sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and training round R𝑅R. Then, we formulate an analytical approximate problem of the original Problem P1 based on the convergence upper bound in Theorem 1. Finally, we develop an efficient algorithm to solve the new problem with insightful sampling principles.

Here, we note that any optimization for minimizing the FL training time has the challenge that, before the model has been fully trained, it is generally impossible to know exactly how different FL configurations affect the FL performance. Therefore, to optimize the FL performance, we need to have a lightweight surrogate that can (approximately) predict what will happen if we choose a specific configuration. We use the convergence upper bound as the surrogate for this purpose, which is a common practice [14, 20, 38, 39, 44].

5.1 Analysis for the expected round time 𝔼​[T(r)​(𝐪)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝐪\mathbb{E}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})]

Since the analytically characterizing the expected round time 𝔼​[T(r)​(𝒒)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\mathbb{E}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})] in (4) is infeasible, we consider the following approximation to characterize how clients’ heterogeneous computation time (i.e., τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}) and heterogeneous communication time (i.e., tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}) affect the optimal client sampling.

Without loss of generality, we order N𝑁N clients such that their computation time are in the ascending order as follows:

τ1≤τ2≤…≤τi≤…≤τN.subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏2…subscript𝜏𝑖…subscript𝜏𝑁\tau_{1}\leq\tau_{2}\leq\ldots\leq\tau_{i}\leq\ldots\leq\tau_{N}. (16)

Then, we show the following theorem that characterizes the lower and upper bounds of 𝔼​[T(r)​(𝒒)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\mathbb{E}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})].

Although we can derive the analytical expression of the lower and upper bound of 𝔼​[T(r)​(𝒒)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\mathbb{E}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})], it is still difficult to use them to approximately solve the optimal sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} in Problem P1. This is because the control variables 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} are in a complex polynomial sum with an order K𝐾K in (18) and (19), which prevents the access for the partial derivatives.

Similarly, for Case 2, the lower and upper bound of 𝔼𝒦​(𝒒)(r)​[T(r)​(𝒒)]subscript𝔼𝒦superscript𝒒𝑟delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{K}(\boldsymbol{q})^{(r)}}\left[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right] in Theorem 2 are the same, as we have 𝔼​[mini∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)⁡{τi}]=𝔼​[maxi∈𝒦(r)​(𝒒)⁡{τi}]=∑i=1Nτi𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑖superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒subscript𝜏𝑖𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑖superscript𝒦𝑟𝒒subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝜏𝑖\mathbb{E}\left[\min_{i\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\left\{\tau_{i}\right\}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\max_{i\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})}\left\{\tau_{i}\right\}\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\tau_{i} when K=1𝐾1K=1.

For the general cases, we can still use 𝔼~​[T(r)​(𝒒)]~𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})] from (25) to approximate 𝔼​[T(r)​(𝒒)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\mathbb{E}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})]. We summarize the insights of the obtained analytical round time in (25) as follows:

  • •

    When we have unlimited or large enough bandwidth ft​o​tsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡f_{tot} (i.e., K​ti/ft​o​t→0→𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡0{Kt_{i}}/{f_{tot}}\rightarrow 0), the approximated expected per-round time 𝔼~​[T(r)​(𝒒)]~𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})] in (25) is determined by the computation heterogeneity τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}, which is independent to sampling number K𝐾K as clients’ computation performs in parallel.

  • •

    In wireless networks, the communication is usually the bottleneck due to the limited bandwidth, e.g., the scale of communication time is larger than the scale of computation time. In particular, when τi≪K​ti/ft​o​t,∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequencemuch-less-thansubscript𝜏𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡for-all𝑖𝒩\tau_{i}\ll{Kt_{i}}/{f_{tot}},\forall i\in\mathcal{N}, the approximated expected round time 𝔼~​[T(r)​(𝒒)]~𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\tilde{\mathbb{E}}\left[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})\right] is roughly linearly increasing with sampling number K𝐾K, as a larger K𝐾K reduces the communication bandwidth of each sampled client to upload the model parameters.

Remark: Although a smaller K𝐾K leads to shorter expected round time, it does not mean a smaller K𝐾K can reduce the total convergence time. This is because the total FL convergence time also depends on the number of training rounds for reaching the target precision. According to our obtained convergence result in Theorem 1, a smaller K𝐾K will leads to a slower convergence rate (e.g., a larger number of rounds R𝑅R for reaching the same error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon). Our experimental results in Section 6 also identify the impact of K𝐾K on the performance of convergence time.

5.2 Approximate Optimization Problem for Problem P1

Based on the approximated expected per-round learning time 𝔼~​[T(r)​(𝒒)]~𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑟𝒒\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T^{(r)}(\boldsymbol{q})] in (25) and by letting the analytical convergence upper bound in (11) satisfy the convergence constraint,888Optimization using upper bound as an approximation has also been adopted in [44, 38, 14, 18]. the original Problem P1 can be approximated as

P2:​min𝒒,R∑i=1Nqi​(K​tift​o​t+τi)​R s.t. 1R​(α​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2K​qi+β)≤ϵ,∑i=1Nqi=1,qi>0,∀i∈𝒩,R∈ℤ+.P2:subscript𝒒𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝑅 s.t. 1𝑅𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾subscript𝑞𝑖𝛽italic-ϵmissing-subexpressionsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖1missing-subexpressionformulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑖0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒩𝑅superscriptℤ\begin{array}[]{cl}\textbf{P2:}\ \min_{\boldsymbol{q},R}&\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\left(\dfrac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)R\\ \quad\text{ s.t. }&\dfrac{1}{R}\left(\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\dfrac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{Kq_{i}}}+\beta\right)\leq\epsilon,\\ &\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}=1,\\ &q_{i}>0,\forall i\in\mathcal{N},\ R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}.\end{array} (30)

Combining with (11), we can see that Problem P2 is more constrained than Problem P1, i.e., any feasible solution of Problem P2 is a subset of that of Problem P1.

We further relax R𝑅R as a continuous variable for theoretical analysis in Problem P2. For this relaxed problem, suppose (𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*}, R∗superscript𝑅R^{*}) is the optimal solution, then we must have

1R∗​(α​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2K​qi∗+β)=ϵ.1superscript𝑅𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝛽italic-ϵ\frac{1}{R^{*}}\left(\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{Kq_{i}^{*}}}+\beta\right)=\epsilon. (31)

This is because if (31) holds with an inequality, we could always find an R′<R∗superscript𝑅′superscript𝑅R^{\prime}<R^{*} that satisfies (31) with equality, but the solution (q∗superscript𝑞q^{*}, R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime}) can further reduce the objective function value. Therefore, for the optimal R𝑅R, (31) always holds, and we can obtain R𝑅R from (31) and substitute it into the objective of Problem P2. Then, the objective of Problem P2 is

[∑i=1Nqi​(K​tift​o​t+τi)]​(α​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2K​qi+β),delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾subscript𝑞𝑖𝛽\left[\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)\right]\left(\alpha{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\frac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{Kq_{i}}}+\beta\right), (32)

which999For ease of analysis, we omit ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as it is a constant multiplied by the entire objective function. is only associated with client sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}. In line with this, P2 can be expressed as

P3:​min𝒒[∑i=1Nqi​(K​tift​o​t+τi)]​(α​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2K​qi+β)s.t.∑i=1Nqi=1,qi>0,∀i∈{1,…​N}.P3:subscript𝒒delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾subscript𝑞𝑖𝛽s.t.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑖0for-all𝑖1…𝑁\begin{array}[]{cl}\textbf{P3:}\ \min_{\boldsymbol{q}}&\left[\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\left(\dfrac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)\right]\left(\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\dfrac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{Kq_{i}}}+\beta\right)\\ \ \ \text{s.t.}&\!\!\!\!\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}=1,\ q_{i}>0,\forall i\in\{1,\ldots N\}.\end{array} (33)

Remark: The objective function of Problem P3 is in a more straightforward form compared to Problem P2. However, to solve for the optimal sampling probability 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}, we need to know the value of the parameters in (33), e.g., Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}, α𝛼\alpha, and β𝛽\beta, which is challenging because we can only estimate them during the training process of FL.101010We assume that clients’ heterogeneous computation time τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}, communication time tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}, and their dataset size proportion pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} can be measured offline.

In the following, we solve Problem P3 as an approximation of the original Problem P1. Our empirical results in Section 6 demonstrate that the solution obtained from solving Problem P3 achieves the target precision with less time compared to baseline client sampling schemes.

5.3 Solving Problem P3

In this subsection, we first show how to obtain the unknown parameters, e.g., Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}, α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta. Then, we develop an efficient algorithm to solve Problem P3. We summarize the overall algorithm in Algorithm 2. Finally, we identify some insightful solution properties.

5.3.1 Estimation of Parameters Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} and βα𝛽𝛼\frac{\beta}{\alpha}

We first show how to estimate βα𝛽𝛼\frac{\beta}{\alpha} via a substitute sampling scheme.111111We only need to estimate the value of βα𝛽𝛼\frac{\beta}{\alpha} instead of α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta each, because we can divide parameter α𝛼\alpha on the objective of Problem P3 without affecting the optimal sapling solution. Then, we show that we could indirectly acquire the knowledge of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} during the estimation process of βα𝛽𝛼\frac{\beta}{\alpha}.

The basic idea is to utilize the derived convergence upper bound in (11) to approximately solve βα𝛽𝛼\frac{\beta}{\alpha} as a variable, via performing Algorithm 1 with two baseline sampling schemes: uniform sampling 𝐪𝟏subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q_{1}} with qi=1Nsubscript𝑞𝑖1𝑁{q}_{i}=\frac{1}{N} and weighted sampling 𝐪𝟐subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q_{2}} with qi=pisubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖{q}_{i}=p_{i}, respectively.

Note that for sampling schemes 𝐪𝟏subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q_{1}} and 𝐪𝟐subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q_{2}}, we only run a limited number of rounds to reach a predefined loss Fssubscript𝐹𝑠F_{s}. We don’t run these schemes until they converge to the precision ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. This is because our goal is to find and run with the optimal sampling scheme 𝐪∗superscript𝐪\mathbf{q^{*}} so that we can achieve the target precision with the minimum wall-clock time.

Specifically, suppose R𝐪𝟏,ssubscript𝑅subscript𝐪1𝑠R_{\mathbf{q_{1}},s} and R𝐪𝟐,ssubscript𝑅subscript𝐪2𝑠R_{\mathbf{q_{2}},s} are the number of rounds for reaching the pre-defined loss Fssubscript𝐹𝑠F_{s} for schemes 𝐪𝟏subscript𝐪1\mathbf{q_{1}} and 𝐪𝟐subscript𝐪2\mathbf{q_{2}}, respectively. According to (11), we have

{(Fs−F∗)​R𝐪𝟏,s≈α​N​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2/K+β,(Fs−F∗)​R𝐪𝟐,s≈α​∑i=1Npi​Gi2/K+β.casessubscript𝐹𝑠superscript𝐹subscript𝑅subscript𝐪1𝑠𝛼𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾𝛽otherwisesubscript𝐹𝑠superscript𝐹subscript𝑅subscript𝐪2𝑠𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾𝛽otherwise\begin{cases}\left(F_{s}-F^{*}\right)R_{\mathbf{q_{1}},s}\approx\alpha N{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}/K+\beta,\\ \left(F_{s}-F^{*}\right)R_{\mathbf{q_{2}},s}\approx\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}{p_{i}G_{i}^{2}}}/K+\beta.\end{cases} (34)

Based on (34), we have

R𝐪𝟏,sR𝐪𝟐,s≈α​N​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2/K+βα​∑i=1Npi​Gi2/K+β.subscript𝑅subscript𝐪1𝑠subscript𝑅subscript𝐪2𝑠𝛼𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾𝛽𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾𝛽\frac{R_{\mathbf{q_{1}},s}}{R_{\mathbf{q_{2}},s}}\approx\frac{\alpha N{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}/K+\beta}{\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}{p_{i}G_{i}^{2}}}/K+\beta}. (35)

We can calculate αβ𝛼𝛽\frac{\alpha}{\beta} from (35) once we know the value of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}.

Notably, we can estimate Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} during the procedure of estimating αβ𝛼𝛽\frac{\alpha}{\beta}. The idea is to let the sampled clients send back the norm of their local SGD along with their returned local model updates, and then the server updates Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} with the received norm values. This approach does not add much communication overhead, since we only need to additionally transmit the value of the gradient norm (e.g., only a few bits for quantization) instead of the full gradient information.

In practice, due to the sampling variance, we may set several different Fssubscript𝐹𝑠F_{s} to obtain an averaged estimation of αβ𝛼𝛽\frac{\alpha}{\beta}. The overall estimation process corresponds to Lines 2–2 of Algorithm 2.

5.3.2 Optimization Algorithm for q∗superscript𝑞\boldsymbol{q}^{*}

We first identify the property of Problem P3 and then show how to compute 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*}.

Lemma 2.

Problem P3 is non-convex.

Proof.

We prove this lemma by showing that the Hessian of the objective function in Problem P3 is not positive semi-definite. E.g., for N=2𝑁2N=2 case, we have ∂2𝔼~​[Ttot]∂2q1=2​α​q2​(K​t2ft​o​t+τ2)​p12​G12q13>0superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇totsuperscript2subscript𝑞12𝛼subscript𝑞2𝐾subscript𝑡2subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏2superscriptsubscript𝑝12superscriptsubscript𝐺12superscriptsubscript𝑞130\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}q_{1}}=\frac{2\alpha q_{2}\left(\frac{Kt_{2}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{2}\right)p_{1}^{2}G_{1}^{2}}{q_{1}^{3}}>0, whereas ∂2𝔼~​[Ttot]∂2q1​∂2𝔼~​[Ttot]∂2q2−(∂2𝔼~​[Ttot]∂q1​∂q2)2=−α2​((K​t1ft​o​t+τ1)​p22​G22q22−(K​t2ft​o​t+τ2)​p12​G12q12)2≤0superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇totsuperscript2subscript𝑞1superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇totsuperscript2subscript𝑞2superscriptsuperscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇totsubscript𝑞1subscript𝑞22superscript𝛼2superscript𝐾subscript𝑡1subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏1superscriptsubscript𝑝22superscriptsubscript𝐺22superscriptsubscript𝑞22𝐾subscript𝑡2subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏2superscriptsubscript𝑝12superscriptsubscript𝐺12superscriptsubscript𝑞1220\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}q_{1}}\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}q_{2}}\!-\!\left(\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial q_{1}\partial q_{2}}\right)^{2}\!=\!-\alpha^{2}\left(\frac{\left(\frac{Kt_{1}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{1}\right)p_{2}^{2}G_{2}^{2}}{q_{2}^{2}}-\frac{\left(\frac{Kt_{2}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{2}\right)p_{1}^{2}G_{1}^{2}}{q_{1}^{2}}\right)^{2}\!\leq\!0, which concludes the proof that Problem P3 is non-convex. ∎

To efficiently solve Problem P3, we define a new control variable

M:=∑i=1Nqi​(K​tift​o​t+τi),assign𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖M:=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right), (36)

where Mm​i​n=mini∈𝒩⁡(K​tift​o​t+τi)≤M≤Mm​a​x=maxi∈𝒩⁡(K​tift​o​t+τi)subscript𝑀𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑖𝒩𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝑀subscript𝑀𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝑖𝒩𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖M_{min}=\min_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)\leq M\leq M_{max}=\max_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right). Then, we rewrite Problem P3 as

P4:min𝒒,Mg​(𝒒,M)=M⋅(α​∑i=1Npi2​Gi2K​qi+β)s.t.∑i=1Nqi=1,∑i=1Nqi​ti=M,qi>0,∀i∈𝒩.P4:subscript𝒒𝑀𝑔𝒒𝑀⋅𝑀𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2𝐾subscript𝑞𝑖𝛽s.t.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖1missing-subexpressionsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝑀missing-subexpressionformulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑖0for-all𝑖𝒩\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P4:}\ \ \min_{\boldsymbol{q},M}&g(\boldsymbol{q},M)=M\cdot\left(\alpha{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{Kq_{i}}}+\beta\right)\\ \ \ \text{s.t.}&\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}=1,\\ &\sum_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}t_{i}=M,\\ &q_{i}>0,\forall i\in\mathcal{N}.\end{array} (37)

For any fixed feasible value of M∈[Mm​i​n,Mm​a​x]𝑀subscript𝑀𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑀𝑚𝑎𝑥M\in[M_{min},M_{max}], Problem P4 is convex in 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}, because the objective function is strictly convex and the constraints are linear.

We will solve Problem P4 in two steps. First, for any fixed M𝑀M, we will solve the optimal 𝒒∗​(M)superscript𝒒𝑀\boldsymbol{q}^{*}(M) in Problem P4 via a convex optimization tool, e.g., CVX. This allows us to write the objective function of Problem P4 as g​(𝒒∗​(M),M)𝑔superscript𝒒∗𝑀𝑀g(\boldsymbol{q}^{\ast}(M),M). Then we will solve the problem by using a linear search method over M𝑀M with a fixed step-size ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0} over the interval [Mm​i​n,Mm​a​x]subscript𝑀𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑀𝑚𝑎𝑥[M_{min},M_{max}].121212We denote M∗​(ϵ0)superscript𝑀subscriptitalic-ϵ0M^{*}(\epsilon_{0}) and the corresponding 𝒒∗​(M∗​(ϵ0))superscript𝒒superscript𝑀subscriptitalic-ϵ0\boldsymbol{q}^{*}(M^{*}(\epsilon_{0})) in the searching domain to approximate the optimal M∗superscript𝑀M^{*} and 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*} in Problem P4. This optimization process corresponds to Lines 2–2 of Algorithm 2.

Remark: Our optimization algorithm is efficient in the sense that the linear search method domain [Mm​i​n,Mm​a​x]subscript𝑀𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑀𝑚𝑎𝑥[M_{min},M_{max}] is independent of the scale of the problem, e.g., number of N𝑁N.

5.3.3 Property of q∗superscript𝑞\boldsymbol{q}^{*}

Next we show some interesting properties of the optimal sampling strategy.

Theorem 3.

Consider the optimal solution of Problem P3 𝐪∗superscript𝐪\boldsymbol{q}^{*}. For any two different clients i𝑖i and j𝑗j with K​tift​o​t+τi≤K​tjft​o​t+τj𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑗\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\leq\frac{Kt_{j}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{j} and pi​Gi≥pj​Gjsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝐺𝑗p_{i}G_{i}\geq p_{j}G_{j}, we have qi∗≥qj∗superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗q_{i}^{*}\geq q_{j}^{*}.

Proof.

We prove this theorem by contradiction. Suppose qi∗<qj∗superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗q_{i}^{*}<q_{j}^{*}, when Ti≤Tjsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝑇𝑗T_{i}\leq T_{j} and pi​Gi≥pj​Gjsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝐺𝑗p_{i}G_{i}\geq p_{j}G_{j}. Then, we can simply let qi′=qj∗,qj′=qi∗formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}^{\prime}=q_{j}^{*},q_{j}^{\prime}=q_{i}^{*} such that qi′>qj′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗′q_{i}^{\prime}>q_{j}^{\prime} and achieve a smaller 𝔼​[Ttot​(qi′,qj′)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇totsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗′\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(q_{i}^{\prime},q_{j}^{\prime})] than 𝔼​[Ttot​(qi∗,qj∗)]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑇totsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(q_{i}^{*},q_{j}^{*})], which concludes the proof. ∎

Theorem 3 shows that the optimal client sampling strategy would allocate higher probabilities to those who have smaller values K​tift​o​t+τi𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i} (e.g., having both powerful computation capability and good communication channel) and larger product value of pi​Gisubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖p_{i}G_{i}. This characterizes the impact and interplay between system heterogeneity and statistical heterogeneity.

Although it is infeasible to derive an analytical solution of 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*} regarding the impact of τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}, tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}, and pi​Gisubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖p_{i}G_{i} on 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*}, we show that when β/α→0→𝛽𝛼0{\beta}/{\alpha}\rightarrow 0 holds for a certain FL task, we have the global optimal solution 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*} of Problem P3 as

qi∗=(pi​GiK​tift​o​t+τi)/(∑j=1Npj​GjK​tjft​o​t+τj).superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝐺𝑗𝐾subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑗q_{i}^{*}={\left(\frac{p_{i}G_{i}}{\sqrt{\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}}}\right)}\Big{/}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N}\frac{p_{j}G_{j}}{\sqrt{\frac{Kt_{j}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{j}}}\right)}. (38)

This is because when β/α→0→𝛽𝛼0{\beta}/{\alpha}\rightarrow 0, we must have (∑i=1Nqi​ti)​βα→0→superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝛽𝛼0\left(\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}t_{i}\right)\frac{\beta}{\alpha}\rightarrow 0 given that ∑i=1Nqi​(K​tift​o​t+τi)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right) is bounded by [Mm​i​n,Mm​a​x]subscript𝑀𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑀𝑚𝑎𝑥[M_{min},M_{max}]. Therefore, the objective of Problem P3 can be rewritten as

min𝒒⁡[∑i=1Nqi​(K​tift​o​t+τi)]​(∑i=1Npi2​Gi2qi).subscript𝒒superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2subscript𝑞𝑖\min_{\boldsymbol{q}}\left[\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}q_{i}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)\right]\left({\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}\frac{p_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}{q_{i}}}\right). (39)

By Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have

(∑i=1N(qi​(K​tift​o​t+τi))2)​(∑i=1N(pi​Giqi)2)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖2\displaystyle\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\left(\sqrt{q_{i}\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)}\right)^{2}\right)\left({\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{p_{i}G_{i}}{\sqrt{q_{i}}}\right)^{2}}\right) (40)
≥(∑i=1N(K​tift​o​t+τi)⋅pi​Gi)2.absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁⋅𝐾subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖2\displaystyle\geq\left(\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\sqrt{\left(\frac{Kt_{i}}{f_{tot}}+\tau_{i}\right)}\cdot{p_{i}G_{i}}\right)^{2}.

Hence, the minimum of (39) is (∑i=1Nti⋅pi​Gi)2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁⋅subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖2\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sqrt{t_{i}}\cdot{p_{i}G_{i}}\right)^{2}, which is independent of sampling strategy 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}. The equality of (40) holds, meaning that the global optimal solution is achieved, if and only if only when (38) holds.

Though 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*} in (38) is valid only for the special case of βα→0→𝛽𝛼0\frac{\beta}{\alpha}\rightarrow 0, the global optimal sampling solution in (38) characterizes an analytical interplay between the system heterogeneity (i.e., τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i} and tisubscript𝑡𝑖{t_{i}}) and statistical heterogeneity (i.e., pi​Gisubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖p_{i}G_{i}).

6 Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the performance of our proposed client sampling scheme. We first present the evaluation setup and then show the experimental results. Our experiment code is available at:
https://github.com/WENLIXIAO-CS/WirelessFL

6.1 Experimental Setup

6.1.1 Platforms

We conduct experiments both on a networked hardware prototype system and in a simulated environment.131313The prototype implementation allows us to capture real system operation time, and the simulation system allows us to simulate large-scale FL environments with manipulative parameters. As illustrated in Fig. 2, our prototype system consists of N=40𝑁40N=40 Raspberry Pis serving as clients and a laptop computer acting as the central server. All devices are interconnected via an enterprise-grade Wi-Fi router. We develop a TCP-based socket interface for the communication between the server and clients with bandwidth control. In the simulation system, we simulate N=100𝑁100N=100 virtual devices and a virtual central server.

6.1.2 Datasets and Models

We evaluate our results on two real datasets and a synthetic dataset. For the real dataset, we adopt the widely used MNIST dataset and EMNIST dataset [10]. For the synthetic dataset, we follow a similar setup to that in [23], which generates 606060-dimensional random vectors as input data. We adopt both the convex multinomial logistic regression model and the non-convex convolutional neural network (CNN) model with LeNet-5 architecture [51].

6.1.3 Training Parameters

For all experiments, we initialize our model with 𝐰0=𝟎subscript𝐰00\mathbf{w}_{0}\!=\!\mathbf{0} and use a SGD batch size b=24𝑏24b=24. We use an initial learning rate η0=0.1subscript𝜂00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 with a decay rate η01+rsubscript𝜂01𝑟\frac{{\eta}_{0}}{1+r}, where r𝑟r is the communication round index. We adopt the similar FedAvg settings as in [8, 16, 32, 23], where we sample 101010% of all clients in each round, i.e., K=4𝐾4K\!=\!4 for Prototype Setup and K=10𝐾10K\!=\!10 for Simulation Setups, with each client performing E=50𝐸50E=50 local iterations.141414We also conduct experiments both on Prototype and Simulation Setups with variant E𝐸E and K𝐾K, which show a similar performance as the experiments in this paper.

6.1.4 Heterogeneous System Parameters

For the Prototype Setup, the computation time for E=50𝐸50E=50 local iterations is almost the same amongst 40 devices, which we measured as τi≈0.5subscript𝜏𝑖0.5\tau_{i}\approx 0.5 second. To enable a more heterogeneous communication time, we control clients’ bandwidth and generate a uniform distribution ti/ft​o​t∼𝒰​(0.22,5.04)similar-tosubscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡𝒰0.225.04t_{i}/f_{tot}\sim\mathcal{U}(0.22,5.04) second, with a mean of 2.632.632.63 second and the standard deviation of 1.391.391.39 second. For the simulation system, we generate clients’ computation and communication time based on an exponential distribution, i.e., τi∼exp⁡(1)similar-tosubscript𝜏𝑖1\tau_{i}\sim\exp{(1)} second and ti/ft​o​t∼exp⁡(1)similar-tosubscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑜𝑡1t_{i}/f_{tot}\sim\exp{(1)} second with both mean and standard deviation as 111 second.

6.1.5 Implementation

we consider three experimental setups.

  • •

    Setup 1: We conduct the first experiment on the prototype system using logistic regression and the EMNIST dataset. To generate heterogeneous data partition, similar to [10], we randomly subsample 33,0363303633,036 lower case character samples from the EMNIST dataset and distribute among N=40𝑁40N\!=\!40 edge devices in an unbalanced (following the power-law distribution) and non-i.i.d. (i.e., each device has 1–10 classes) fashion.151515The number of samples and the number of classes are randomly matched, such that clients with more data samples may not have more classes.

  • •

    Setup 2: We conduct the second experiment in the simulated system using logistic regression and the Synthetic dataset. To simulate a heterogeneous setting, we use the non-i.i.d. S​y​n​t​h​e​t​i​c​(1,1)𝑆𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑡𝑖𝑐11Synthetic\ (1,1) setting. We generate 20,5092050920,509 data samples and distribute them among N=100𝑁100N\!=\!100 clients in an unbalanced power-law distribution.

  • •

    Setup 3: We conduct the third experiment in the simulated system using non-convex CNN and the MNIST dataset, where we randomly subsample 15,1291512915,129 data samples from the MNIST dataset and distribute them among N=100𝑁100N\!=\!100 clients in an unbalanced (following the power-law distribution) and non-i.i.d. (i.e., each device has 1–6 classes) fashion.

We present the estimation process and results of α/β𝛼𝛽\alpha/\beta for the three experiment setups in Table II.

6.2 Experimental Results

In this section, we first compare the performance of our proposed client sampling scheme (Algorithm 2) with different sampling baselines. Then, we evaluate the impact of the key system parameter on the total convergence time. We evaluate the wall-clock time performances of both the global training loss and test accuracy on the aggregated model in each round for all sampling schemes. We average each experiment over 202020 independent runs. For a fair comparison, we use the same random seed to compare sampling schemes in a single run and vary random seeds across different runs.

6.2.1 Comparison with Different Sampling Schemes

We compare the performance of our proposed client sampling scheme with three benchmarks 1) uniform sampling, 2) weighted sampling, and 3) statistical sampling where we sample clients according to statistical heterogeneity without system heterogeneity. Benchmarks 1–2 are widely adopted for convergence guarantees in [23, 21, 22, 24, 25]. The third baseline is an offline variant of the proposed schemes in [32, 33].161616The client sampling in [32, 33] is weighted by the norm of the local stochastic gradient in each round, which frequently requires the knowledge of stochastic gradient from all clients to calculate the sampling probabilities. Fig. 3, Fig. 4, and Fig. 5 show the results of Setup 1, Setup 2, and Setup 3, respectively. We summarize the key observations as follows.

  • •

    Loss with Wall-clock Time: As predicted by our theory, Fig. 3(a), Fig. 4(a), and Fig. 5(a) show that our proposed sampling scheme achieves the same target loss with significantly less time, compared to the rest of baseline sampling schemes. Specifically, for Prototype Setup 111 in Fig. 3(a), our proposed sampling scheme spends around 717171% less time than uniform sampling, 393939% less time than statistical sampling, and 303030% less time than weighted sampling for reaching the same target loss. Fig. 5(a) highlights the fact that our proposed sampling works well with the non-convex CNN model, under which the naive uniform sampling cannot reach the target loss within 4,00040004,000 seconds, indicating the importance of a careful client sampling design. Table 333 summarizes the superior performances of our proposed sampling scheme in wall-clock time for reaching target loss in all three setups.

  • •

    Accuracy with Wall-clock Time: As shown in Fig. 3(b), Fig. 4(b), and Fig. 5(b), our proposed sampling scheme achieves the target test accuracy much faster than the other benchmarks. Notably, for Setup 222 with the target test accuracy 787878% in Fig. 4(b), our proposed sampling scheme takes around 444444% less time than uniform sampling, 626262% less time than statistical sampling, and 606060% less time than weighted sampling. We can also observe the superior test accuracy performance of our proposed sampling schemes in Prototype Setup 111 and non-convex Setup 333 in Fig. 3(b) and Fig. 5(b), respectively.

  • •

    Loss with Number of Rounds: Fig. 3(c), Fig. 4(c), and Fig. 5(c) show that our proposed sampling scheme requires more training rounds for reaching the target loss compared to some of other baselines. This observation is expected since our proposed sampling scheme aims to minimize the wall-clock time instead of the number of rounds.

6.2.2 Impact of Client Sampling Number K𝐾K

Fig. 666 shows the impact of the client sampling number K𝐾K for our proposed optimal sampling scheme for Setup 222. We see from Fig. 6(a) and Fig. 6(b) that as K𝐾K increases, the time for our proposed optimal sampling scheme reaching the target loss and accuracy first decreases and then increases. In particular, the shortest time for reaching the target loss with is 617.1617.1617.1s under K=4𝐾4K=4, compared to 4778.14778.14778.1s, 1272.51272.51272.5s, and 2021.62021.62021.6s under K=1𝐾1K=1,101010, and 161616, respectively. This demonstrates the trade-off design for the number of K𝐾K in wireless networks, as a smaller K𝐾K benefits the per-round time (shown as in Theorem 222) but requires more rounds for convergence (shown as in Theorem 111), whereas a larger K𝐾K benefits the number of rounds for convergence but yields a longer per-round time due to limited wireless bandwidth.

7 Conclusion and Future Work

In this work, we studied the optimal client sampling strategy that addresses the system and statistical heterogeneity in FL to minimize the wall-clock convergence time in wireless networks. For system heterogeneity, we proposed an adaptive bandwidth allocation scheme for the sampled clients in each round with arbitrary sampling probabilities to address the straggling effect. For statistical heterogeneity, we obtained a new tractable convergence bound for FL algorithms with arbitrary client sampling probabilities. Based on the bound, we formulated an analytically non-convex wall-clock time minimization problem. We developed an efficient algorithm to learn the unknown parameters in the convergence bound and designed a low-complexity algorithm to approximately solve the non-convex problem. Our solution characterizes the interplay between clients’ communication delays (system heterogeneity) and data importance (statistical heterogeneity) on the optimal client sampling design. We also identify a trade-off design for the number of sampled clients in each round, which balances the impact of wireless bandwidth limitation and convergence rate. Experimental results validated the superiority of our proposed scheme compared to several baselines in speeding up wall-clock convergence time.

Our client sampling optimization marks an initial effort to tackle system and statistical heterogeneity in FL. Looking ahead, we plan to transform our offline sampling strategy into an online one. This adaptation caters to practical wireless scenarios with changing channel conditions. Furthermore, we’re considering a joint optimization of client sampling with other control variables, like the number of sampling instances or local iterations. This joint approach could further cut down total learning time.
